PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government of Azerbaijan has requested ADB the project preparatory technical assistance 
(TA) to prepare investment program. ADB support in the form of TA is necessary to complete the due 
diligence in economic and financial, safeguards and poverty areas, and procurement. This TA will review 
technical due diligence including tolling systems, implementation periods for all tranches in the investment 
program and support in achieving the readiness for tranche 1. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  Major activities of the TA are (i) inception, (ii) feasibility study, and (iii) investment program 
design. These include (i) for inception, the preparatory activities; (ii) for the feasibility study, the activities 
for  investment  program  preparation,  covering  engineering,  economic,  institutional  and  procurement, 
social, resettlement, climate, and environmental aspects and their due diligence. The engineering study 
will include geological, topographical, hydrological surveys, preliminary pavement design, cost estimates, 
and implementation plan. The economic study will conduct traffic surveys and the economic feasibility. 
The  social  and  environmental  studies  will  prepare  environmental  assessment,  poverty  and  social 
assessment,  gender  analysis  and  action  plan,  and  resettlement  plans,  creation  of  a  stakeholder 
communication and engagement plans; The institutional feasibility study will cover the current institutional 
arrangements for project implementation, asset management including maintenance, SWOT analysis and 
implementation plan. The procurement study will assess current procurement arrangements, identify 
areas and reasons for delays, and develop procurement mechanisms/plans; and (iii) for investment 
program  design,  preparation  of  draft  report  and  recommendation  of  the  president,  and  the  facility 
administration manual (FAM). The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A3.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million equivalent, of which $1.4 million equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-Others).  
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other 
in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The  TA  will  require  66  person-months  (PMs)  of  consulting  services  (firm  international  and 
national). A consulting firm will be recruited using quality cost-based selection with 90:10 ratio and a full 
technical proposal, and engaged on output-based contract. The TA, among other tasks, will address the 
following aspects relating to the ensuing loan: (i) procurement plan; (ii) EA/IA capacity assessment and 
an  action  plan  to  minimize  procurement  and  financial  management  risks;  and  (ii)  indicative 
implementation schedule. The outline terms of references of TA consultants are described in paras. 5–19. 
Table A3.3: Summary of Consulting Services Requirement

5.  Team  Leader/Transport  Specialist  (International,10  PMs)  will  be  civil  engineer  with  post-
graduation in highways/bridges, and 15 years of relevant experience. The team leader will coordinate all 
activities within the team and with stakeholders, and review the roads/bridges based on multi-criteria to 
include traffic demand analysis and social and environmental impacts, tolling, etc., including subsector 
updates. Also, prepare preliminary designs with climate resilience and road safety features, geometric, 
pavement and structural designs; total costs, design and monitoring frameworks, and all TA documents. 
 
6.  Geotechnical Specialist (International, 3 PMs) will be civil engineer with post-graduation in 
geotechnical engineering, and 15 years of relevant experience; will review the existing geotechnical 
aspects of roads/bridges and carry out investigations and develop improvement designs; review the 
specifications and quantities of the failed areas; and determine the most appropriate improvements, 
considering constructability and sustainability, and provide relevant inputs to other specialists.  
 
7.  Climate Change Specialist (International, 2 PMs) will be civil engineering with post-graduation in 
Hydrology/climate, 10 years relevant experience; conduct a climate risk and vulnerability assessment, 
cost and benefits analysis of adaptation options;  propose the most viable climate change adaptation 
options    based  on  the    cost-benefit  analysis  of  climate  proofing  designs;  design  a  disaster  risk  
management    plan  with  more  operational  emphasis  and  participation  of  communities;  and  review 
http://www.adb.org/documents/guidelines-climate-proofing-investment-transport-sector-road-
infrastructure-projects, and base recommendations on the guidelines, and explore grant financing. 
8.  Toll  Roads  Specialist  (International,  3  PMs)  will  be  civil  engineer  with  post-graduation  in 
transportation/transport economics, or business administration with 15 years relevant experience; provide 
tolling  options,  operational  requirements,  and  assess  commercial  viability;  and  recommend  tolling 
systems, and inputs for economic and financial analysis, model structuring, and concession agreement.  
 
9.  Pavement/Material Engineer (International, 3 PMs) will be civil engineer with specialization in 
pavement materials, with 12 years’ experience in pavements and testing of pavement materials as per 
ASTM, AASHTO standards; and undertake surveys, suitability of materials and preliminary pavement 
design; and improvements considering road safety, climate resilience, and whole life cost approach. 
 
10.  Bridge/Structural Engineer (International, 4 PMs) will be civil engineer and specialized in 
bridges, and 12 years relevant experience will review the existing and proposed bridges, and recommend 
improvement and construction methods, undertake preliminary design and support the team leader. 
 
11.  Transport Economist (International, 3 PMs) with degree in transport economics and 15 years 
relevant experience; will undertake economic evaluation1 by following related ADB guidelines; estimate 
economic internal rate of return, and NPV; undertake sensitivity analysis and quantitative risk analysis;2 
and develop performance indicators for monitoring; and draft the benefit monitoring framework. 
 
12.  Environment Specialist (International, 3 PMs) will be civil/environmental engineer or post-
graduate  in  environmental  sciences  and  12  years  relevant  experiences.  The  environmental  impact 
assessment will be performed as required and comply with both the Government’s regulations and ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement 2009 (SPS), and draft the environment management plan (EMP), provide 
environmental  management  costs  and  its  implementation  and  monitoring.  Also,  incorporate  public 
consultation results into the design, and prepare an environmental assessment and review framework. 
 
13.  Resettlement Specialist (International, 3 PMs) with degree in sociology/social sciences, and 12 
years relevant experience, will assess resettlement impacts and lead the preparation of the resettlement 
plans (RPs), and assess impacts on ethnic minority peoples, through consultations with affected persons 
following Government laws and SPS. Also, conduct due diligence on acquired lands, prepare due 
diligence reports, RPs to retrofit to meet SPS and a land acquisition and resettlement framework (LARF).  
                                                
1  The economic analysis should cover ten key areas as outlines in `Key Areas of Economic Analysis of Investment 
Projects: An Overview (2013)’ and consider the economic value of land in terms of its opportunity costs. 
2  In accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of Projects.

14.  Institutional Development Specialist (International, 2  PMs)  with  degree  in  engineering  or 
management, post-graduate degree/diploma, 12 years relevant experience will undertake institutional 
assessment, prepare an institutional model for road network management and project implementation; 
design the program management, PIU structure, and recommend institutional capacity improvements. 
 
15.  Social Development and Gender Specialist (International, 2 PMs) with degree in sociology or 
social  sciences,  10  years  relevant  experience,  will  conduct  poverty  and  social  evaluation,  impact 
assessments, develop an awareness plan about road safety, HIV/AIDS and human trafficking; prepare a 
gender action plan and support social participation and empowerment of women; conduct stakeholder 
consultation; incorporate results into design; and prepare impact matrix and recommendations.3 
 
16.  Procurement Specialist (International, 4 PMs) with degree in civil engineering or law,12 years 
relevant experience, will undertake risk assessment and prepare Procurement Risk Assessment and 
Management Plan (P-RAMP); update capacity assessment and prepare procurement plan, capacity 
building plan and address concerns identified in the draft project procurement related review; prepare 
master bidding documents, RFP; projections of contract awards and disbursements, and implementation 
schedule; draft the FAM, and assist in advance actions and in design and monitoring frameworks. 
  
17.  Financial Specialist (International, 3 PMs) will be professional charted accountant, with 12 years 
of relevant experience, and undertake financial evaluation, as per ADB guidelines-Financial Management 
Starter  Kit;  estimate  financial  internal  rate  of  return,  carry  out  sensitivity  analysis,  quantitative  risk 
analysis, and develop performance indicators. Review EA’s financial management, internal control, and 
risk assessment, and provide recommendations; design fund-flow mechanism and identify disbursement 
procedures; assess budgetary implications to MOT, prepare cost estimates, and financing plan. 
 
18.  Project  Planning  Specialist  (International,  2  PMs)  with  degree  in  project  planning/civil 
engineering, 12 years relevant experience; will prepare a detailed project implementation schedules and 
recommend critical resources; develop monitoring plan, in coordination with other specialists and ADB. 
 
19.  Cost Estimate Specialist (National, 4 PMs) will be a civil engineer/quantity surveyor, with 10 
years’ experience in costing, quantity estimating of roads. The other national consultants will support 
respective international specialists and the team leader, and provide necessary local coordination. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  MOT  will  be  the  executing  agency.  ARS/MOT  will  be  responsible  for  TA  implementation.4 
ARS/MOT will assign counter staff/engineers to work with consultants, and also provide an office space 
for the consultants. The TA will be implemented over 15 months, commencing February 2015 and ending 
by April 2016. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.  
 
Table A3.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule  
 
       Major Milestones  Completion Date 
       TA approval  December 2014 
       Inception mission  March 2015 
       Interim report  September 2015

       Draft bidding documents                                                       D   e  c e  m   b  e  r    2  0 15 
       Final report                                                                            M   a  r c  h    2  0  16 
        Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
 
                                                
3  In accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty (2006). 
4  Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
